moves.1. c4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. g3 Nc6 4. Bg2 Bb4: Here were at the starting point of thousands of games.
moves.5... O-O 6. O-O e4 7. Ne1:
The older move this knight heads for e3 via c2 in order to strengthen White's control over d5.
Alternative variation: 7.Ng5 Bxc3 8.bxc3 Re8 [has been the critical variation for many years.]
moves.7... Bxc3:
The classic example of
Alternative variation: 7...Re8 [?!] 8.Nd5 [!  is ... Portisch-Huebner, Tilburg 1983:] h6 9.d3 Bxe1 10.Rxe1 Ne5 11.dxe4 [!] Nxc4 12.Nxf6+ Qxf6 13.Qc2 Qc6 14.Bf4 Ne5 15.Rac1 Qxc2 16.Rxc2 c6 17.Rd1 [with a large advantage.]
moves.8. dxc3 Re8:
!?
Alternative variation: 8...h6 [has been played in order to prevent White's next. Then another Portisch game from the sametournamentwent] 9.Nc2 Re8 10.Ne3 d6 ( 10...b6 ) 11.b3 ( 11.Qc2 [and there are several moves here, but analogous to the game is] Re5 [!?] 12.Rd1 [with some difficulties for Black.] ) a5 12.Qc2 a4 13.Rb1 axb3 14.axb3 Ne7 15.Rd1 Bd7 16.c5 [!?] dxc5 17.c4 Ra6 18.Bb2 Qc8 19.Ra1 Rxa1 20.Bxa1 Nf5 21.Qd2 Nd4 22.Bxd4 cxd4 23.Qxd4 c6 24.Qb6 Be6 25.h4 h5 26.Rd4 Nd7 27.Qa5 f5 28.Bh3 g6 29.Qc3 Nf8 30.Ng2 Rd8 31.Nf4 Bf7 [?] 32.Rxe4 [L Portisch-Izoria, Warsaw POL 2005.]
moves.10... Re6: Alternative variation: 10...exf3 11.Nxf3 Re6 [(else the move Bxf6 will soon decimate Black's kingside)] 12.Nd4 Nxd4 13.Qxd4 d6 14.Bd5 Re5 15.Bxf6 gxf6 16.Rad1 [with a clear advantage.]
moves.11. Nc2 Qe7:
?  Now Black is lost. But things were bad anyway after
Alternative variation: 11...h6 12.Bxf6 Qxf6 13.Ne3 Re8 14.Qc2 Qe7 15.Rfd1
moves.19... Rxd5: Alternative variation: 19...Re6 20.Rxg5+ hxg5 21.Qxg5+ Ng6 22.Ne7+ [, winning Black's queen.]
moves.20. cxd5 d6 21. Rxg5+: A win in the old style of English Opening play.
